newsitem.title: GERMANY: VW says cautiously optimistic about 1997.
newsitem.headline: VW says cautiously optimistic about 1997.

text.p: German carmaker Volkswagen AG, hurt by weak domestic sales so far this year, said on Thursday it was cautiously optimistic about reporting higher results for 1997.
VW management board chairman Ferdinand Piech said in a speech to the carmaker's annual general meeting that plans to introduce new models during the year may provide risks.
"For the full-year 1997 we expect results above last year," Piech said, noting the prediction was based on a continuation of current economic conditions.

VW chief financial officer Bruno Adelt said the carmaker would seek to boost foreign sales in the coming years, noting the percentage of foreign sales rose to 63 percent in 1996 from about 61 percent in 1995.
But VW's sales have weakened in Germany, in part due to potential customers waiting for the introduction of the new Golf model at the Frankfurt car show in September.
VW's sales from January to May fell about 11 percent to 238,000 vehicles despite a 6.8 percent rise in global sales during the five-month period to 1.1 million vehicles.
